Posts.Content: Jul 9, 2008 05:46AM ellenoire wrote: Beach Mom, is this the Recipe? Alaska Deb posted it on another Board. First the brownie... 4 sq. unsweetened chocolate 3/4 c. (1 1/2 sticks) butter 2 c. sugar 4 eggs 1 tsp. vanilla 1 c. flour 1 c. chopped pecans 1. Heat oven to 350 degrees. 2. Microwave chocolate and butter in large microwave bowl at high 2 minutes or until butter is melted. Stir until chocolate is completely melted. 3. Stir sugar into chocolate. Mix in eggs and vanilla until well blended. Stir in flour and nuts. Spread in greased 13 x 9 inch pan. Actually, I line the pan with foil and then grease it. That way I can pull the whole brownie out of the pan at once cut it easier when it is done. Cheesecake layer... 16 oz cream cheese, softened 2/3 cup sugar 2 eggs 4 Tbs flour 1 tsp almond extract Blend together with a fork and drop by spoonfuls on top of the brownie batter and carefully smooth out. The cream cheese has to be room temp and you will get a little bit of the brownie swirled into the cheesecake....that's ok, just try and get it as smooth as you can. If you don't want to make the rocky road fudge layer, you can add 1 cup of mini chocolate chips to the cheesecake and then swirl it together with the chocolate layer before you bake...that is yummy too! 4. Bake aprox 40 minutes or until toothpick inserted in center comes out with fudgy crumbs and the cheesecake is set. Don't over cook! Cool on the counter, and then in the fridge. Rocky Road Fudge... 2 cups granulated sugar 3/4 cup evaporated milk 2 ounces baking chocolate, unsweetened 1 tablespoons light corn syrup 2 tablespoons butter 1 teaspoon vanilla 1 cup miniature marshmallows 1/2 cup chopped pecans sprinkle marshmallows over the cooled brownies then put in the freezer while making fudge. Lightly butter the interior of a 2-quart saucepan; add sugar, milk, chocolate, and corn syrup. Cook over medium high heat until the mixture begins to boil. Continue boiling gently, stirring frequently, until the mixture reaches the soft ball stage or registers about 234° to 238°. You can do this step in the microwave it you watch it carefully. Remove saucepan from heat; add butter and vanilla without stirring. Let cool for about 30 minutes, then beat with a wooden spoon until the fudge just begins to thicken. Add chopped nuts and beat for a few more minutes, until it begins to lose its gloss but is still pourable. Pour over marshmallows. When fudge is firm, cut brownies and eat....YUM

Posts.Content: Jul 13, 2008 10:03PM ellenoire wrote: yes, my hair is/was naturally curly. I specialise in teaching people how to take care of their hair (mostly curly clients, but I teach anyone) with no sulfates, no silicone and no petroleum products. My curly clients are frizz free all year round if they follow my instructions ( and I scold them if they don't) My hair was waist length when we cut it off for charity.  The joke right now is: many people get curly hair as a result of chemo ( aka chemocurly) ... what happens if mine comes back straight?    I am starting a section on my site for chemo and cancer patients to teach them how to "look good, feel better" without chemical laden products that likely assisted in giving many of us cancer in the first place.    cheers, Noelle

Posts.Content: Aug 5, 2008 01:53AM ellenoire wrote: Here is your update Roberta, I am almost 3 weeks out of my last chemo. Still lots of tingling in my finger tips and feet, and my heartburn is yucky. I took myself of the Nexium to see if that was adding to my bloating and the Zantac 150's just are not cutting it. My energy level is pretty good when I can sleep. I work for the next 2 days on the floor at the store so we will see how I do there. I work for hours at home, but I am sitting down most of the time.  My eyelashes are done for I am sorry to tell you. I think I have 4 left between both eyes.  The hot flashes have lightened up a little too, so I can sleep a little better. I just read that it can take up to a year for menstruation to start again if it is going to. Personally I would prefer to have it back as opposed to menopause.  Any word from Angie?   Take Care everyone!

Posts.Content: Sep 19, 2008 07:47AM ellenoire wrote: Ladies be sure to gently exfoliate those bumps several times a week. If they get inflamed then stop. Ask your doc to look at them, no major rush but if you are seeing a doc soon then... They might be ingrown hairs, they might be hairs trying to grow in, they might be keratosis or dermatitis( minor but annoying skin conditions)
